content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: A well-written solution, fun and has different scenarios.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Fun theme, well written, multi-defender average cases are an interesting complication for Reverse.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Clear description, fun and easy enough for clash of code.

Goal
* Please rewrite as follows for clarity (the example has been deleted because an example has been shown in Example section):

In a game, every attacker and defender belongs to one of three types: {{Grass}}, {{Water}}, and {{Fire}}.

• {{Grass}} is effective against {{Water}}.
• {{Water}} is effective against {{Fire}}.
• {{Fire}} is effective against {{Grass}}.
• In all other cases, the attack is considered useless.

Each battle consists of one attacker and one or more defenders. The defender types are provided as a single string, with individual types separated by {{+}}.

For each battle, you must determine the <<result>> of the attack based on how many defender types the attacker is effective against:

• If the attacker is effective against <<more than half>> of the defenders, the result is {{Effective}}.
• If the attacker is effective against <<less than half>> of the defenders, the result is {{Useless}}.
• If the attacker is effective against <<exactly half>> of the defenders, the result is {{Average}}.

Input
* Please rewrite as follows for clarity:

<<Line 1:>> An integer [[N]] for the number of battles.
<<Next 2[[N]] lines:>> For each battle:
 • <<Line 1:>> A string representing the type of the attacker.
 • <<Line 2:>> A string representing the type(s) of the defender(s).

Output
* Please change "attack" to "battle".

* Please format "Effective", "Useless" and "Average" as {{constants}} instead of [[variables]].

Constraints
* Please change 1024 to 10 because N is never greater than 3 in the cases.

Cases
* Each test and its corresponding validator should be similar (but not the same). Hence, please revise Validators 1 to 3 by swapping the order of defenders' types.

* Expand Test 6 and Validator 6 to satisfy the following conditions:
  • N = 9.
  
  • Each attacker-result combination appears exactly once (attacker = Grass/Water/Fire, result = Effective/Useless/Average).
  
  • The number of defenders per battle varies, covering all values from 8 to 11 as evenly as possible, i.e. there are battles with 8, 9, 10 and 11 defenders.
  
  • Try to test edge situations as much as possible, e.g. [4 effective + 5 useless] or [5 effective + 4 useless] when there are 9 defenders, [4 effective + 6 useless] or [5 effective + 5 useless] or [6 effective + 4 useless] when there are 10 defenders, etc.

Thanks.

Thanks for your commenting.
This is my first time creating a puzzle.
Thus I might made many mistakes about the format. 
You're helping me a lot and making the puzzle more readable.

No problem.

* I don't understand how a single defender can have repeating types.

* The current cases are still not enough to cover different scenarios. Please expand the cases as I mentioned in my last comment.

Thanks.

I used to regard the defender as the big boss with multiple types, but he shouldn't have repeating types.
Thus I thnk you are right. This is the best way to represent my game.
I have changed all of that.
Thanks for your commenting!!

Thank you for your response and follow-up. There's just a bit more refinement needed to ensure balanced case coverage:

* In the visible tests, when the number of defenders is EVEN, there are several "Average" outcomes (Tests 4, 6 and 7) but no "Effective" outcomes. Please add an "EVEN + Effective" scenario to Test 7, without modifying the existing battles.

* In the validators, when the number of defenders is greater than 1 and ODD, there are only "Effective" outcomes (Validators 5 and 6) but no "Useless" outcomes. Please add an "ODD + Useless" scenario to Validator 7, without modifying the existing battles.

Thanks again.

I have added cases in Test 7 and Validator 7 to test different scenario.
I really appreciate your help.
Thank you very much.
